column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=[0293] Voltages may be applied to the electrodes in patterns for a short period of time and a check on the focus or astigmatism made.
#Text=The check may be made, for instance, by an image sensor.
#Text=In addition, sensors on the camera or in this case the lens, may detect motion of the camera or lens.
#Text=Motion sensors would include accelerometers, gyroscopes, angular velocity sensors or piezoelectric sensors mounted on the liquid lens or a portion of the optic train very near the liquid lens.
#Text=In one embodiment, a table, such as a calibration table, is then constructed of voltages applied and the degree of correction or voltages needed for given levels of movement.
#Text=More sophistication may also be added, for example, by using segmented electrodes in different portions of the liquid so that four voltages may be applied rather than two.
#Text=Of course, if four electrodes are used, four voltages may be applied, in many more patterns than with only two electrodes.
#Text=These patterns may include equal and opposite positive and negative voltages to opposite segments, and so forth.
#Text=An example is depicted in FIG. 34C.
#Text=Four electrodes 3409 are mounted within a liquid lens housing (not shown).
#Text=Two electrodes are mounted in or near the non-conducting liquid and two are mounted in or near the conducting liquid.
#Text=Each electrode is independent in terms of the possible voltage that may be applied.
#Text=[0294] Look-up or calibration tables may be constructed and placed in the memory of the augmented reality glasses.
#Text=In use, the accelerometer or other motion sensor will sense the motion of the glasses, i.e., the camera on the glasses or the lens itself.
#Text=A motion sensor such as an accelerometer will sense in particular, small vibration-type motions that interfere with smooth delivery of images to the waveguide.
#Text=In one embodiment, the image stabilization techniques described here can be applied to the electrically-controllable liquid lens so that the image from the projector is corrected immediately.
#Text=This will stabilize the output of the projector, at least partially correcting for the vibration and movement of the augmented reality eyepiece, as well as at least some movement by the user.
#Text=There may also be a manual control for adjusting the gain or other parameter of the corrections.

#Text=Note that this technique may also be used to correct for near-sightedness or far-sightedness of the individual user, in addition to the focus adjustment already provided by the image sensor controls and discussed as part of the adjustable-focus projector.
#Text=[0295] Another variable focus element uses tunable liquid crystal cells to focus an image.
#Text=These are disclosed, for example, in U.S.
#Text=Pat.
#Text=Appl.
#Text=Publ.
#Text=Nos. 2009/0213321, 2009/0316097 and 2010/0007807, which are hereby incorporated by reference in their entirety and relied on.
#Text=In this method, a liquid crystal material is contained within a transparent cell, preferably with a matching index of refraction.
#Text=The cell includes transparent electrodes, such as those made from indium tin oxide (ITO).
#Text=Using one spiral-shaped electrode, and a second spiral-shaped electrode or a planar electrode, a spatially non-uniform magnetic field is applied.
#Text=Electrodes of other shapes may be used.
#Text=The shape of the magnetic field determines the rotation of molecules in the liquid crystal cell to achieve a change in refractive index and thus a focus of the lens.
#Text=The liquid crystals can thus be electromagnetically manipulated to change their index of refraction, making the tunable liquid crystal cell act as a lens.
#Text=[0296] In a first embodiment, a tunable liquid crystal cell 3420 is depicted in FIG. 34D.
#Text=The cell includes an inner layer of liquid crystal 3421 and thin layers 3423 of orienting material such as polyimide.
#Text=This material helps to orient the liquid crystals in a preferred direction.
#Text=Transparent electrodes 3425 are on each side of the orienting material.
#Text=An electrode may be planar, or may be spiral shaped as shown on the right in FIG. 34D.
#Text=Transparent glass substrates 3427 contain the materials within the cell.
#Text=The electrodes are formed so that they will lend shape to the magnetic field.
#Text=As noted, a spiral shaped electrode on one or both sides, such that the two are not symmetrical, is used in one embodiment.
#Text=A second embodiment is depicted in FIG. 34E.
#Text=Tunable liquid crystal cell 3430 includes central liquid crystal material 3431, transparent glass substrate walls 3433, and transparent electrodes.
#Text=Bottom electrode 3435 is planar, while top electrode 3437 is in the shape of a spiral.
#Text=Transparent electrodes may be made of indium tin oxide (ITO).
#Text=[0297] Additional electrodes may be used for quick reversion of the liquid crystal to a non-shaped or natural state.
#Text=A small control voltage is thus used to dynamically change the refractive index of the material the light passes through.
#Text=The voltage generates a spatially non-uniform magnetic field of a desired shape, allowing the liquid crystal to function as a lens.
